name: Self-hosting
tagline: A self-hosted environment focused on deployment, security fundamentals, and day-to-day operations.

keyPoints: Essential security measures scoped to realistic threats for a personal, internet-exposed service (automatic updates, restricted access, firewall, intrusion prevention).
Reverse proxy with automated TLS certificate renewal.
Containerized services orchestrated with Docker Swarm.
Self-hosted mail service for application needs.
Designed for small-scale, personal production use.

popTagline: Set up to gain hands-on experience with deployment, security basics, and everyday operational concerns in a self-hosted environment.

overview.mainContent: This project covers the self-hosting of my personal websites and applications, from deployment to maintenance. I operated the full system end-to-end, without managed platform guarantees.
keyPoints: Full-stack deployment: host personal websites and apps with complete control.
Docker orchestration: Swarm for container management, secrets for secure data handling.
Reverse proxy & routing: Traefik for dynamic HTTPS routing, with Nginx used inside images for static sites.
Security: disable root access, configure UFW, fail2ban for brute-force protection.
Automated Deployments: Implemented a reusable CI / CD pipeline based on bash scripts & GitHub workflows.
Monitoring: Grafana + Prometheus for insights into system performance.
overview.after: The result is a flexible setup that supports multiple applications, evolves with my needs, and serves as a practical learning ground for real-world deployment concerns.

purpose.title: Purpose
keyPoints: To understand what actually happens beyond local development.
To deploy applications without vendor lock-in or hidden complexity.
Build a platform capable of supporting a variety of projects, databases, and services.
To gain confidence operating production systems, even at small scale.
purpose.after: This was as much a learning project as a practical one: I wanted to remove the “black box” aspect of hosting and infrastructure.

constraints.title: Constraints
keyPoints: Cost transparency was critical: predictable, low monthly expenses.
Freedom of tooling: no restriction on databases, runtimes, or architectures.
Maintainability over cleverness: simple setups that I can reason about and debug alone.
Personal scale: optimized for small projects, not premature enterprise complexity.
constraints.after: This was as much a learning project as a practical one: I wanted to remove the “black box” aspect of hosting and infrastructure.

choices.title: Self-managed infrastructure over managed platforms
choices.mainContent: I deliberately avoided turnkey platforms that abstract away deployment details. While convenient, they often limit flexibility and can hide operational costs or constraints.
choices.after: Running my own setup forces explicit decisions and provides a clearer mental model of the system.

choices.title: Incremental, modular setup
choices.mainContent: Rather than designing a “perfect” infrastructure upfront, I built it incrementally:
keyPoints: Start simple.
Add components only when a real need appears.
Refactor when complexity justifies it.
Understanding the real costs of cloud infrastructure and the trade-offs of full control vs managed services.
How to monitor and troubleshoot live systems with Grafana and Prometheus.
choices.after: This mirrors how I approach application architecture and helps keep operational complexity under control.

choices.title: Automation where it pays off
choices.mainContent: I automated repetitive and error-prone steps (deployment, updates, basic monitoring) but avoided over-automation. If automation adds more abstraction than value, it is deferred.
choices.after: The goal is confidence and clarity, not maximal automation.

challenges.title: Cost predictability vs scalability
challenges.mainContent: Cloud horror stories often come from systems that scale implicitly and bill unexpectedly. To avoid this, I chose setups with fixed, predictable costs, accepting manual scaling as a trade-off.
challenges.after: This decision reduced anxiety around experimentation and made infrastructure decisions more deliberate.

challenges.title: Debugging without a safety net
challenges.mainContent: When something breaks on self-hosted infrastructure, there is no platform support to fall back on. Early issues forced me to:
keyPoints: Improve logging and observability.
Be systematic when diagnosing failures.
Favor simpler configurations that are easier to reason about.
challenges.after: This significantly improved my operational discipline.

challenges.title: Balancing learning with reliability
challenges.mainContent: It is tempting to constantly tweak infrastructure to try new tools. I learned to separate:
keyPoints: Stable, proven components (that stay untouched).
Experimental parts (where learning is the goal).
challenges.after: This balance keeps production reliable while still allowing exploration.

keyPoints: Infrastructure choices shape application architecture more than expected.
Simplicity is a competitive advantage in operations, especially solo.
Understanding deployment and hosting improves development decisions upstream.
Tool freedom is valuable, but only if paired with discipline and clear constraints.
learned.after: Most importantly, this project reinforced my preference for understanding systems end-to-end, rather than relying on opaque abstractions. That mindset now informs how I design, build, and deploy all my projects.
